question.question-text: What is the professor mainly discussing?

answer-list.answer-text: Insects that feed on plants
Animals that feed on insects

answer-text.exp: Plants that use insects to survive

answer-list.answer-text: Insects that are attractive to plants

question.explain-text: In the lecture, the professor states that today, we're going to be talking about insectivorous plants and that insectivorous plants are plants that trap and assimilate insects in order to sustain life. From this, it can be determined that the professor is mainly discussing plants that use insects to survive. The third answer is therefore the best answer to this question.

question.question-text: Why is the professor discussing this topic?

answer-list.answer-text: He is lecturing about something that the students will see the next day.
He is preparing the students for an exam that is tomorrow.
He is explaining something that the students have just seen.
He is discussing something that the students will be required to read.

question.explain-text: In the lecture, the professor states that as you know, we have a field trip tomorrow and that we'll be going to the botanical gardens, and we're going to be seeing some insectivorous plants there at the beginning of the lecture and ends the lecture with you'll need it for the trip tomorrow. From this, it can be determined that the professor is discussing the topic because he is lecturing about something that the students will see the next day. The first answer is therefore the best answer to this question.

question.question-text: What does an insectivorous plant get from an insect?

answer-list.answer-text: All of its nutrients
Chlorophyll
Digestive liquid

question.explain-text: In the lecture, the professor states that insectivorous plants…consume their insect victims in order to get the nitrogen they need. This means that an insectivorous plant gets nitrogen from an insect. The third answer is therefore the best answer to this question.

question.question-text: According to the lecturer, how widespread are insectivorous plants?

answer-list.answer-text: There are hundreds of varieties in the world.
They exist in 500 countries in the world.
They exist only in North America.
There are five different types throughout the world.

question.explain-text: In the lecture, the professor states that there're perhaps 500 known species of insectivorous plants worldwide. This means that there are hundreds of varieties in the world. The first answer is therefore the best answer to this question.

question.question-text: What is stated in the lecture about the Venus flytrap?

answer-list.answer-text: It is the largest insectivorous plant.
It is found only in South America.
It has moveable parts.
It has only one trap leaf.

question.explain-text: In the lecture, the professor states that the Venus flytrap catches insects by suddenly snapping the ends of one of its trap leaves around an insect. This means that it has moveable parts. The third answer is therefore the best answer to this question.

question.question-text: What is stated in the lecture about the sensory bristles?

answer-list.answer-text: They are divided into two parts.
There are three of them.
They are on the outside of the leaf.
They cause the trap leaf to close.

question.explain-text: In the lecture, the professor states that inside the two parts of the trap leaf are three sensory bristles, sensory bristols which resemble tiny hairs and that when an insect touches the bristles inside a trap leaf, the two surfaces of the leaf shut instantaneously. From this, it can be determined that there are three sensory bristles and that the sensory bristles cause the trap leaf to close. The second and fourth answers are therefore the best answers to this question.
